hint.text: Approximate the value of R to be \(8.3 \frac{J}{mol K}\)

solution.text:
\(H_2O (l) \rightarrow H_2O(g)\)
\(\Delta H = \Delta U + \Delta n_gRT\)
\(\implies \Delta U = \Delta H - \Delta n_gRT\)

Approximate the value of R to be \(8.3 \frac{J}{mol K}\)

Substitute values from the above information and solve for 1 mole:
\(\Delta U_ {mol} = (40.66 - 1 \times 8.3 \times 373) \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
\(\implies \Delta U_ {mol} = (40.66 - 3.096) \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
\(\implies \Delta U_ {mol} = 37.564 \frac{kJ}{mol}\)

Now given that there are _{j}_ moles:
\(\Delta U_ {total} = 37.564 \times _{j}_ kJ\)\(\implies \Delta U_ {total} = _{{37.564 * j}}_ kJ\)

content.text: The enthalpy of vapourisation for 1 mol of water at 100\(^ \circ \) C and 1 bar is 40.66\(\frac{kJ}{mol}\). Calculate the internal energy change, when _{j}_ moles of water is vaporised at 100\(^ \circ \) C and a pressure of 1 bar.
